div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7266] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, August 14, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £9 to Brindisi. The cobined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles. During the Monsoon season the express streamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 pm and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 pm on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about August 25 | R.M.S "Ortana" will leave Suez about September 3.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Orentes" will leave Port Said about August 15 | R.M.S. “Omrah" will leave Port Said about August 29
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Warwichshire 7,966 tons, leaves about August 17.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, leaves about August 31.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,708 tons, leaves about August 23.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons leaves about September 6,

Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS, 31-12-905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Ramses now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, August 29, to be followed by S.S. Seti.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

S.S. Mandalay 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about September 3 for London.
S.S. Irrawaddy 7890 Tons will leave PORT SAID about September 17 for Liverpool.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arragnements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about August 4 and September 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about August 18.
East African Line.
To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about July 4 and August 3.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
OPENS 1ST NOVEMBER, 1905
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia
Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its
own grounds with garden and lawn tennis groundsat back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons.
Magnificent sallè à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest
class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts.
English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit every one.
For further particulars apply to
GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, AUGUST 14, 1905.

div.head: OUR NEXT GOVERNMENT’S FOREIGN POLICY.
div.p: If all Radical leaders spoke with the knowledge and moderation employed by Sir Charles Dilke, when discussing foreign affairs, their patriotism would be much more in evidence than has, unfortunately, been the case of late. Lord E. Fitzmaurice also deserves praise for his frank acceptance of the principle that continuity of policy in our relations with other Powers should be, and must be, strictly observed. It is most refreshing and stimulating to have these utterances from representative Radicals after the constant wavering of the Opposition chief. There is the more likelihood that Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman would, if promoted to the Premiership, come to the sound conclusion that instability of purpose in directing the external affairs of the greatest and most widespread Empire in the world would inevitably replace Great Britain in that position of isolation which, not so long ago, crippled her influence among the nations. The proposal to renew our treaty of alliance with Japan, in more extended form, cannot be finally judged on its merits until the de-tails are made known in full. But it is a long step towards its adoption that the bare ‘idea of this new concordat should have re-ceived general approval recently gp both sides

of the House. It is manifest that owing to the changes in the balance of Asiatic power and influence resulting from the Russo-Japanese conflict, the whole political situation in the Far East has completely altered. Up to the present the alliance has merely bound Great Britain to help the insular Power, should any other nation interfere in the war on the side of Russia. That was a sufficient object to aim at when hostilities began, and the world owes to it the isolation of both combatants in a comparatively narrow area. But there are other points of danger in Asia to the allies-points where conflict would be inevitable were either to break away from the league of peace. It is, therefore, a perfectly sound and statesmanlike policy on the part of His Majesty's Ministers to renew the agreement in such an enlarged shape as may safeguard the whole of Asia from the devastations of war.

It is obvious that the Russian Government would be much less likely to break the peace it aware that Japan was closely associated with Great Britain in its maintenance against all disturbers. There is a moral force as well as a military in alliances: here in Europe the Dual Alliance has continuously operated, ever since it came into being, as a check on the possible aggressiveness of the Triple Allianoe directed from Berlin Chauvinists at St Petersburg and Moscow would think, we may make sure, once, and twioe, about a march to the Indus if that suicidal endeavour would bring upon their over-grown Empire a Japanese invasion of Eastern Siberia. It is this restrictive force on pugnacious proclivities which lends so much value to the enlargement of the present treaty; for one thing, it would render that farther partition of China which is believed to find favor in august quarters at Berlin, well-nigh impracticable. For the Celestial Empire, now so weak and impotent, could then rely on receiving naval and military assistance from the two most powerful fighting nations in Asia; and, with that support, could safely afford to smile at the ‘mailed fist.”

As to Africa although it would be premature regard all difficulties in the Congo State, dne to bad administration, as ended, improvements are being introduced generally, while the Congo Government has unreservedly undertaken to give effect to the report of the investigating Commission as soon as it is rendered. It is not unnatural that British philanthropists should display impatience at the secrecy which characterised the inquiry for a time. Bat now that it is moving more quickly in the required direction it would be a mistake on their part to goad such a very willing horse as the present Cabinet It is much the same in the case of Turkey. The Government is doing all in its power to influence the Sultan to introduce administrative and financial reforms without further delay, but Abdul Hamid still shows marked reluctance to be hurried along a path he does not desire to tread. It may be hoped, however, that the slumberous air of Yildiz Kiosk will be wholesomely stirred by the solemn warning which fell from Lord -Percy lately. Without any mincing of phrases, he counselled the Turkish Government to reform its method of rule in Macedonia and else- where, lest “His Majesty’s Government should have to reconsider their attitude.” The Saltan is sufficiently sagacious to place the right construction on this plain intimation, especially as it represents the united resolve of all the Great Powers. Even Germany, so reluctant to give him offence, has at last come into line with the rest of Europe on the burning question of financial reform and its collaterals, and we imagine that here at all events the coming Radical Government is certain to imitate its predecessors in office. It is only over South African matters that a certain uneasiness prevails as to “C. B.’s” intentions, but we doubt whether any revolutionary changes are likely to be made by a Cabinet that is not likely to be supported by a large and united majority.

div.head: PEACE CONFERENCE.
DISCUSSION OF FIRST CLAUSE.
IMPORTANT POINTS UNDECIDED.
div.p: Portsmouth (N.H.), August 12. It is cod firmed that the Russian reply rejects the payment of an indemnity, and the cession of territory, it declares that Russia is not vanquished. She has suffered reverses, but is not obliged to accept peace at any cost. It throws the responsibility for the war on Japan.
( Reuter.)

Portsmouth (U.S.A.), August 12. The peace conference has met . twice. The Russians have given their answer. The Japanese will meet to morrow to consider the answer. Signs point to an amelioration of the situation.
(Havas)
New York, August 12. The newspapers assert that in the case of the negotiations breaking down, Marshal Oya-ma will attack General Linievitch.
Havas.)
St. Petersburg, August 12. The newspapers and public opinion are unanimous in considering the Japanese conditions outrageous.
{Havas)

Portsmouth (N.H.), August 13. The discussion of the first clause of the peace conditions lasted all yesterday afternoon and was then adjourned, but the two main points of the negotiations, viz., the indemnity and the cession of Saghalien have been left temporarily in abeyance.
(Reuter).
Portsmouth (U.S.A.), August 13. The peace conference did not meet to-day. it has adjourned until to-morrow.
(Havas.)
THE BLACK SEA MUTINEERS.
LIGHT SENTENCES.

St. Petersburg, August 13. The sentences on the Black Sea mutineers are unexpectedly light, as the authorities fear to take extreme measures. Fifteen have been acquitted, five sentenced to penal servitude for life, and the rest to lighter punishment.
FRANCE AND ENGLAND.
PARLIAMENTARY LUNCHEON TO FLEET.

London, August 12. At the Parliamentary luncheon to the French officer at Westminster Hall, Mr. Balfour said that Great Britain and France have too Often been divided, but that for the future their interests throughout the world are identical.
(Reuter)

London, August 12. The officers of the French fleet have been entertained to luncheon by Parliament The Chancellor, the Speaker, Mr. Balfour, and Admiral Caillard drank to the perpetual friendship of the two countries amidst enthusiastic cheering.
(Havas.)
FAMINE IN SOUTHERN SPAIN.
PEASANTS RAIDING FARMS.

Madrid, August 12. The famine in Southern Spain is getting worse daily. Bands of peasants ate killing flocks, and attacking farms, the inmates of which are defending themselves with fire-arms The governor of Cadiz has telegraphed that he cannot be responsible for the rural peace,
EARTHQUAKE AT MACAO.
Macao, August 12. There have been continuous earthquake shocks for nine hours. Crowds of people are filling the parks, and steamers are leaving for Hong-Kong crammed with passengers.
THE FRENCH ARMY.

Paris, August 13. M. Loubet, in making a speech at vill- neuve-sur Rhone, said that the army, inacces sible to pernicious doctrines, would defend the flag in case of necessity; it was the best gua rantee of peace.
(Havas.)
YELLOW FEVER IN AMERICA.
New Orleans, August 13. The yellow fever here is spreading in the most serious manner. 107 fresh cases and 9 deaths took place yesterday.
(Reuter).
CURE FOR LEPROSY DISCOVERED

Manila, August 13. It is believed that the Board of Health has discovered a cure for leprosy by means of Rontgen- rays. Twenty-five cases have bee treated for six months, six of which are apparently cured, whilst all have improved.
(Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Fayoum Light Railways.—The receipts of the Fayoum Light Railways Company for the last ten days of July amounted to L.E. 762.423 mm. The total receipts for the month amounted to L.E. 2,123.978 mm.

Suez Canal— 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 10th inst., 8 of which were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German. The receipts for the day were frs. 293,690.62, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 2,964,740 82.

Stray and Ownerless D|ogs found in the Esbekieh district of Cairo to-night and at dawn to-morrow, and those found in the Bonlac district to-morrow night and at dawn of the 16th inst., will be poisoned by the -police.

THE Plague. — Twenty cases of bubonic plague were notified in Egypt during the week ending Saturday last. Eighteen of these oc-cur ed at Alexandria and two at "Port Said. | Since January 1 there have in all been 221 cases, as compared with 765 during the correspond- ing period last year. Three deaths occurred in Alexandria on Saturday and one yesterday.

Street Accidents.—A cyclist who was riding along Minetlel Bassal-street on Sunday afternoon ran into an Italian woman, who was knocked down, and sustained severe injuries to her head. Another accident occurred at the Customs the same afternoon, a Greek woman being run over by a native who was riding on horseback; and who was also severely injured.

cattle PLAGUE. During the week ending last Saturday nine deaths from cattle plague were reported in Egypt, all of which occurred at kalionb. The number of deaths during the corresponding period last year was 584. The total number of deaths, since the commencement of the epidemic is to 147,433, dis-tributied as follows : — Gouvernorats, 895 ; Lower Egypt 54,291 ; Upper Egypt 92,247:

TRAMCAR Accident.—A Sudanese, Suroor Abdulla by name, belonging to the Coastguards service, Alexandria, in dismounting from a tram, fell, and received injuries sufficiently severe to necessitate his removal to hospital. The man asserts that the conductor started the tram before he had dismounted, and so caused him to be thrown off by the jerk, whilst the conductor denies having done so, and says that the man sustained his injuries by getting off the tram whilst in motion, contrary to the regulations. An inquirt into the matter is being made by the authorities.

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and merchants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquires can obtain further particulars from our London office,'36, New'Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

The Rev. Roland Wormell assisted, and more than 70 boys and girls spent a most enjoyable afternoon. After partaking of a sumptuous tea, which was provided by Mr. G. B. Alderson, they all adjourned to the lawn, where they disported themselves in all manner of games and races, egg-spoon race, three legged race, tug of war, boys versus girls, etc., for which numerous prize were given, and presented by Mrs. Anastas to each winner. There was also a large number of consolation prizes, thereby making every little heart bright and happy. Several ladies and gentlemen were present to assist in entertaining the children. The proceedings terminated with hearty cheers for Mr. G? B. Alderson, Mr. and Mrs. Anastas, and the ladies and gentlemen who had assisted, and the singing of ‘God save the King” We may add that Mrs. Anastas deserves the thanks of all members of the Church of England in Alexandria for her seven years’ unceasing labours among the children of St. Mark’s Sunday School, whose appreciation of which is seen at a glance, whenever this kind-hearted lady is in their midst.

div.head: obituary.
M. HUMBERT EBANO.
div.p: ' It is with deep regret that we learn of the death on trie 10th inst. of M. Humbert Ebano, acting manager of the Stock Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo. He was an able, active, energetic official of the bank, and was held the highest esteem, as shown by the position of trust to which he had been promoted just before his illness. He had joined the bank from the very day of its foundation. We tender our most sincere condolence to his bereaved brother, and to his other relatives.

div.head: BAMLEH BATHING ACCIDENT
FUNERAL OF DECEASED OFFICERS.
div.p: At the inquest held on Saturday before Mr. F. G. Freeman, H.B.M’s Vice-Consul, at Ras el Tin hospital, it was proved that the sad accident, by which Captains Stokes and. Carey lost their lives, took place between 4.30 and 5.0 p.m, In his evidence Captain Crawley, A.S.C., stated that hearing a noise at about 5 p.m. he looked from the balcony ot the Beau Rivage Hotel and saw Capt. Carey swimming against the current, and making little or no progress Stokes having disappeared. Hearing him call for help Capt. Crawley ran to the beach, took his coat off, and went in getting to within five or six yards of the swimmer, when the current carried him away to the east. He made a second attempt, this time with a rope, and was himself carried under, and had to be hauled ashore, when Capt. Carey had disap-peared. The other evidence dealt mainly with the attempts at restoring animation in the ease of Capt. Carey, which appear to have been persevered with as long as there was any hope. The jury which consisted of Messrs. J. T. Atkin, J. Gunn, and C. D. Stacey gave a verdict in accordance with the evidence, and recorded their hearty commendation of Capt. Crawley’s courageous attempt at a rescue.

At 5 p.m. on Saturday the military funeral started from the Bourse. Shortly before that hour a strong detachment of the 2nd Royal Inniskillking Fusiliers had,arrived by special train from Cairo, and marched to the square, where it was mot by the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, ‘i he procession was preceded by the Egyptian mounted police, who kept the streets clear as far as the Rosetta gate. The military mounted police led the long column, followed by the band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, which played the Dead March. The two gun carriages, which conveyed the bodies to their resting place were draped with the Union Jack, and we were glad to note that almost all the Europeans and Syrians who were present— and the cortege passed through crowded streets —sainted the dead. General Bullock, Maj. Ludlow.D.A.A.G., Admiral Sir R M. Blomfield, and several of the principal members of the Head Quarters staff, representatives of the Governorat and the Egyptian Army, and severa! Well known members of the Consular Body and the British community followed. The Iunis-killings detachment, and the 2nd Royal Berkshires brought up the rear. At the Rosetta gate the procession was joined by the firing party, and the two bands of the Inniskillings who played the Dead March as far as the cemetery. The Rev. A. H. Manning, acting-Chaplain to the forces, conducted the burial service by the grave, where a number of beautiful wreaths had been laid by the comrades and friends of the deceased. The coffins were carried into the cemetery by the. sergeants and staff sergeants of the Inniskiliing Fusiliers. On the conclusions of the burial service, the usual volleys were fired over the grave, and the general salute to the dead, and the "Last Post” brought the sad ceremony to an end

The following special army order has been issued from the Headquarters, Cairo ‘It is with profound regret that the General Officer Commanding announces the deaths of Captain E. S. Carey, Adjutant, 2nd Bn. Royal Innis-killing Fusiliers and of Captain C. H. G. V. Stokes, 2nd Bn Royal Inniskiliing Fusiliers, who were accidentally drowned while bathing at Alexandria on 11th August. Both these Officers did distinguished service during the late war, and the Server sustains a great loss by their untimely
THE HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE.

We mentioned in a recent issue that the above company, which has taken Over the business of Mr. Stangen, the well known German tourist agent, contemplated starting a river passenger service between Cairo and Assouan during the tourist season of 1906-7, to compete with the old established lines of Messrs. Cook and Son, and the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company. Later it was announced that negotiations had been to entered into between the latte and the Hamburg-Amerika Company to work the two services in conjunction. It appears, from what we now learn, that the negotiations between the two companies are still in progress, and there is every reason to believe that a satisfactory arrangement will be arrived at sood. Several meetings have already taken place in Europe between the representatives of both sides, but nothing definite has yet been decided.
ESBEKIEH GARDENS

By kind permission of Lt.-Col. C. J. Markham and Officers, the band of the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifles will perform the following programme of music at the Esbekieh Gardens to-morrow (Tuesday), commencing at 9 p.m. 1 Two sten—Minnehaha - Losey. 2 Selection—Three Little Maids Rubens. 3 Intermezzo Bal d’Knfants—Jaxouo. Soloist. Mus. U. Arnold. 6 SiMohamed labes saifah (by desire), 7 Ballet Music—Sylvis Delibes. « 8 Patrol-U.8.A.- Coxmoore. Regimental March-Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King Thomas Brown, Bandmaster.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Papayanni S.S. Avon, which left Tangiers on Saturday evening, is expected to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday morning next, with passengers and mails.
The Messageries Maritimes mail-boat, Por- tugal, which left Marseilles on the 10th inst., passed the straits of Messina on Saturday, and s expected to arrive at Alexandria to-morrow,

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE OUTRAGE
another Theory.
div.p: We have been shown a letter from a British resident in Constantinople which gives the following news of the bomb outrage against H.I.M. the Sultan. "in a country like this, where nothing in the shape of public meetings is allowed, interest,even in such an occurrence, dies down very quickly. It is, generally speak-ing, dangerous for an ordinary Turk to talk politics, excepting in the privacy of his own house, where, it is to be presumed, no members of the Khafieh are present. Consequently there has been no public display of indignation—or of approbation-and all that I get from peasants, boatmen, and the like, is—“We think it was an Armenian, but, please, may we change the subjeot ?” Preposterous stories were current about the extent of the casualties, many supposing that at least 1,000 persons were disposed of. As a matter of fact, I think, seventeen were killed and forty odd wonnded. The Saltan behaved quite coolly, realising that the danger to his person was passed, and keeping off the crowd of officers and ministers that gathered round him; as much, I fancy, from a desire to avoid another attack with cold steel, as to stop the panic. The police scoured the town, arrested several hundreds of harmless folk, and sent back to their homes as many Armenians and Bulgars not domiciled here, as they could find. They have, as yet, hit on no clue worth anything, though they got up a yam about an india-rubber tyred carriage, which has appeared in all the papers. Many of the best-informed residents think it more probable that the outrage was the work of plotters at the palace—perhaps of the Albanian body guard, who are terribly out of hand at present. Of course the revolutionaries, Armenians and Macedonians, took the “oredit” for a cruel and clumsy outrage, and the police are only too glad to be spared the trouble of ferreting about among the secretaries and chamberlains at Yildiz Kiosk, some of whom are disaffected scoundrels.”
SHOCKING SUICIDE IN CAIRO

A French gentleman, of the name of Emile Jullien, committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping from a third floor balcony into the street. He sustained frightful injuries to the head, and death was almost instantaneous. The deceased, who lived at the Maison Sabbagh, in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, with his brother and his family, had been suffering for over a year from melancholia which, at times, assumed an acute form. This was the case on Saturday night, when he was carefully watched. He ran twice to the balcony early in the morning with the intention of jumping over, and was prevented, hot the third time he succeeded in evading his watchers, and accomplished his purpose. The late Monsieur Emile Jullien was a batchelor of 39 years of age, and had formerly been employed at the local Mixed Tribunals.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer, who is spending his holiday in Scotland, will leave Marseilles on October 13, on his way back to Egypt. Mr. P. W. Mitchell, Adviser to the Ministry of (the Interior, will leave for England tomorrow by the P. & 0. HH. Arabia. Saba Pasha, who is now in Europe, is ex-pooled to return to Alexandria, ami resume his functions as Post Master General, on the 4th prox. Supernumerary Lieutenant Cyril P. Grindle, 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, has been promoted to full rank, vice C. Wighton, resigned. Major H. G. French, Royal Army Medical Corps, has been granted sick leave from the 18th inst. until December 17. Six months’ sick leave has been granted to Major A. R. Gilbert, D.S.O., 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment. Moheb Bey, Mudir of Sharkieh, left for Europe on Saturday by the Austrian mail boat

div.head: The Nile FLOOD.
MR. WEBB’S Report
div.p: In my last note I pointed out the following, viz (a) that the levels of the river had been unprecedently low from the middle of May, and that the irrigation of the summer crops had only been rendered possible by the supplementary supply derived from the Assouan-Reservoir. (b) That the flood was very late in its earlier stages, and promised to be low.

The Assouan Reservoir was emptied on 20th July (one month later than in 1904), since which date the supply in the river has been maintained by the flood, which reached Assouan nearly one month later than the usual time, and then not in sufficient quantity to satisfy the demands for the irrigation of the “sharaki” durah lands as well as the cotton crops, so that it will be found necessary to maintain the canals in the Delta and Middle Egypt until probably the middle of this month.

The rice crop, has, naturally, suffered in many places, but the cotton crop has been entirely saved by the Assouan Reservoir. Both in the Delta and Middle Egypt it is stated to be most excellent, and unless unfavorable climatic conditions prevail in September next, the crop should be a record one. The Cotton worm has been practically extirpated, owing to the very energetic and successful measures organised by the Ministry of Interior.

The irrigation of the “sharaki" durah lands has been somewhat retarded, but is in advance of the years previous to the construction of the weir below the Delta Barrage and the Assiout Barrage : the delay has caused com plaint, bat it is doubtful if any real damage has been done. It may be noted that in 1899, the irrigation of “sharaki” durah lands was not allowed until the 6th August in the Delta, whilst in the present year it was allowed 10 days earlier. Owing to the rise now taking place the irrigation of all crops in the Delta and Middle Egypt is absolutely assured, and no further anxiety need be felt throughout the flood. Regulation is being carried on both at the Delta, Zifta and Assiout Barrages; the latter will be completely closed within the next few days.

It may interesting to note that op to date not a drop of water has passed down the two branches of the Nile into the sea. The “sadd” in the Rosetta branch, however, is not likely to stand more than a few days longer. This fact, alone, shows how very late the flood has been, and how usefuls the barrages have been in utilising every drop of water available.
At Khartoum.—The following table gives a comparison of the gauges at Khartoum tor 1905, last year, and the two very low years, 1899 and 1902, viz :—

It will be seen from the above that the levels are 1.50 metres below those of last year, which wan by no means a good year, and 25 to 30 centimetres below those of 1899 and 1902, both yearn of extremely low floods. The Hood In the While Nile has been fairly normal that it the Blue Nile completely failed. Captain Lyons, who has most skilfully and so entifically studied the question, states that there wan great deficiency in the rains in Abyssinia during May and June, that in July matters improved, and “that it seems probable that, so far as indications show, the August rains are more likely to be poor than good." The prospects therefore, are not promising,and although a rise has lately taken place on the Blue Nile and the Atbara, the present indication is that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902.
At Assouan.—The following table gives a comparison of the gauges at Assouan for 1905, last year, the very low years 1899 and 1902, as well as the average for the past 30 years.

div.head: Sport and Play
Home Cricket
div.p: London, August 12. Leicestershire beat Hampshire by an innings and 21 runs. Sussex beat Derbyshire by an innings and 41 runs. Yorkshire beat Surrey by five wickets. Worcestershire beat Somerset shire by six wickets. Warwickshire beat Northamptonshire by ten wickets. Lancashire beat Kent by eight wickets. Essex v. Notts drawn. The Australians beat Middlesex by 132 runs.
(Reuter)

div.head: A.S.C.
div.p: The following are the entries for the August Skye Meeting :

San Stefano Plate. - H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's Shneiman ; Omar Bey Sul-tan and Ahmed Bey Bakri’s Oyama Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Gladiateur II; Ishack Bey Hussein’s Faik; Ishack Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din’s Lahek H.E. Khalil Pasha Khayat’s Loulou ; Mr. A. J. Sursock's Nigri ; Mr. Ekisler’s Temsah.

SCHUTZ Plate. —H.H. Prince Omar pasha Toussoun's Fayad ; Ibrahim Bey Cherit and Ellie Bey Sursock's Mikado ; Ibrahim Bey Cherif's St. Frusquin ; Ishack Bey Hussein’s El Tahawi and Salama (late Arabi) Mr. J. Hogami’s Tonnerre; Mr. Ekisler's Tensah

Galloway Plate.—Omar Bey Sultan's and Ahmed Bey Bakri’s, Saiad II; Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s Sattam ; Mr. Nicolas Soussa and Kamel Effendi Maher’s Mahronsse ; Ishack Bey Hussein’s Fadgban ; Ishack Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din’s, Lahek H.E. Khalil Pasha Khayat's, Suleik : H.E. Mohar-rem Pasha Chehin’s Bibico and Aeolus : Mr. A. J. Sursock's Sans Pareil; Mr. E. Karam’s Tembel; Saleh Bey Yaghen’s Bulkeley.

Selling Race.—Capt, G.B. Byrne’s China-man; Omar Bey Sultan’s and Ahmed Bey Bakris, Oyama, Ibrahim Bey Cherifs Jean; Ishack Bey Hussein’s Saib H.E. Kalil| Pasha Khayat’s Moushba; Mr. A.J. Sursock's Prince Soleil; Mr. E. Karam's Boheme; Mr. Ed Buetro’s Malgre Tout; Mr. J. N. Simonda Derry Boy ;Messrs. W.B. Rees and G.H. Barker’s Firefly.

Bulkeley Plate.—H.H, Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's Hadban ; Mr. J. N. Simond's The Bard ; Ibrahim Bey Cherifs Gladiateur II; and St. Frusquin; Hussein Bey Sioufi's Catcout; Mr. Micola Soussa and Kamel Ef-fendi Maher’s Mahrousse; Ishack Bey Hussein’s Nessim ; H.E. Khalil Pasha Khayat’s Loulou ; H. E. Moharrem Pasha Chehin’s Cupid; Mr. A.J. Sursock’s Sans Pareil; Saleh Bey Yaghen’s Bulkeley (late Spectre).

Sidi Gaber Plate.—H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun’s Gayad ; Omar Bey Sultan and Ahmed Bey Bakri’s Sayad II. ; Ibrahim Bey Cherif and Elie Bey Sursock’s Mikado; Ishack Bey Hussein’s Moofid ; H.E. Moharrem Pasha Chehin’s Mizzaud ; Saleh-Bey Yaghen’s Mabsout (late Bonjonr).

The clerk of the course requests ns to state that owing to the course and polo ground being watered, Polo will be played this week on Friday instead of Thursday. On Thursday the Polo ground will be availa-ble for golf.

div.head: Passenger Lists
div.p: Departures
Arrivals

From the above it will be seen that the Assouan gauge is now 2.74 metres below last year and 3.01 metres below the average of the last 30 years. Taking into consideration the rise south of Assouan, now taking place, it is probable that the flood of this year will follow that of 1902. According to the rules of the Public Works Ministry, a “bad Nile” is declared when the Assouan gauge does not reach 13 pics on the 15th August; as there is no possibility of this occurring, the Ministry has decided to declare a “bad Nile” at once, and instructions have been issued to take the same measures as were carried out to meet he low flood of 1902. The area of “sharaki” in 1902 was 128,000 feddana, and, unless conditions rapidly improve, it is quite probable that the same area may remain unirrigated by the present flood.

Summary —In the Delta and Middle Egypt the irrigation of all crops is assured by the Delta, Zifta and Asriont Barrages, though the durah crops must necessarily be late. In Upper Egypt the conditions are far from favorable and indicate a flood similar, if not inferior, to that of 1902.
